qas.question: When was the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka created?
The Sri Lankan Supreme Court's decisions override what?
Sri Lankan law mixes what two categories of jurisprudence?
What majority is necessary in the Sri Lankan Parliament to dismiss a president and the Court?

plausible_answers.text: the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka

qas.question: What do capital-law and civil-law blend together to make?
The president of the country may play a role in what type of cases?

context: In Sri Lanka, <b4_0>the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka<b4_0/> was created in <a0_0>1972<a0_0/> after the adoption of a <b5_0>new Constitution.<b5_0/> The Supreme Court is the highest and final superior court of record and is empowered to exercise its powers, subject to the provisions of the Constitution. The court rulings take precedence over <a1_0>all lower Courts<a1_0/>. <b6_0>The Sri Lanka judicial system<b6_0/> is complex blend of both <a2_0>common-law and civil-law<a2_0/>. In some cases such as <b7_0>capital punishment<b7_0/>, the decision may be passed on to the President of the Republic for clemency petitions. However, when there is <a3_0>2/3<a3_0/> majority in the parliament in favour of president (as with present), the supreme court and its judges' powers become nullified as they could be fired from their positions according to the Constitution, if the president wants. Therefore, in such situations, Civil law empowerment vanishes.
